repository.corpname: NYU Abu Dhabi, Archives and Special Collections

did.abstract: Consists of audiovisual recordings, chiefly of performances of taarab music by members of the Zanzibar-based Dhow Countries Music Academy (DCMA), including recordings of concerts held in Zanzibar as well as on the campus of New York University Abu Dhabi. Also included are studio recordings of individual performers, interviews, and a copy of a concert program.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Content is arranged into three series: Documentaries, Performances, and Studio Recordings.

bioghist.head: Historical note
bioghist.p: The Dhow Countries Music Academy was founded in Stone Town, Zanzibar in 2002, with the aim of preserving and fostering an appreciation for traditional forms of music, such as taarab, that are unique to this region. The use of the term "dhow countries" was meant to encompass the countries and cultures along the eastern coast of Africa and the Arabian Peninsula which were traditionally bound together, commercially and culturally, through regular trade brought by the ships known as "dhows," which traveled from the Arabian Gulf and southern Arabia to ports along the Indian Ocean coast of Africa during the monsoon seasons. As such, the music--while rooted in the traditions of Zanzibar and coastal Tanzania and Kenya--has elements from such far-flung places as Kuwait, the United Arab Emirates, Yemen, Oman, and the Comoros Islands, as well as Iran, Pakistan and India.

The academy trains students in playing traditional musical instruments, such as the qanun, oud, or violin, as well as those used in other musical traditions, such as jazz, pop music, or Afro-fusion. In addition to training students at the academy, the DCMA sends members out to primary schools around Zanzibar to educate local children in these musical traditions, and gives performances at venues around Zanzibar, as well as internationally.
[Source: website of DCMA, https://www.zanzibarmusic.org/home/landing , accessed on 6 November 2024]

processinfo.head: Processing information
processinfo.p: The collection was processed by Safeya Alblooshi and Rebecca Pittam, 2022-2024, and the finding aid was created by Brad Bauer, November 2024.

scopecontent.head: Content Description
scopecontent.p: The Dhow Countries Music Academy collection consists of audiovisual recordings, chiefly of performances of taarab music by members of the Zanzibar-based Dhow Countries Music Academy (DCMA), including recordings of concerts held in Zanzibar as well as on the campus of New York University Abu Dhabi. Also included are studio recordings of individual performers, interviews, and a copy of a concert program.

The recordings dated January 2018 were recorded as part of a January-term class offered by professors Carlos Guedes and Scandar Copti of New York University Abu Dhabi (NYUAD), in which they and their students traveled to Zanzibar, in order to study taarab music and the cultures with which it is linked. The recordings from this period consist of student-made video documentaries as well as audiorecordings of two separate performances at the DCMA's performance space in Zanzibar City.

The recordings created in September 2019 were related to a visit by members of the DCMA to NYUAD, in order to perform in a concert at the university's Arts Center, titled "Sufism vs. Modernism." This concert featured musicians and vocalists from the DCMA, as well as performances by Sufi vocalist Fathy Salama and Egyptian Sufi chanter Sheikh Mahmoud Tohamy. In addition to audio and video recordings of this concert, members of the DCMA were separately recorded in a studio in the Arts Center during their visit, and some of those recordings are included in this collection.

In cases where ambisonic methods of recording were used, up to 11 different microphones were placed in front of the individual performers, and individual vocal and musical tracks were created, which were then subsequently mixed into the recordings available in this collection. While the solo track performances are not included in this collection, they may be made available to researchers upon request.

odd.head: Contents
odd.p: Short audiovisual documentary about Saidi Bhai, qanun maker from Zanzibar, done in the context of the NYU Abu Dhabi J-Term course "Audiovisual ethnography: Music and heritage in Zanzibar."

odd.head: Contents
odd.p: Mixed audio recording of a live performance by members of the Dhow Countries Music Academy, consisting of Zanzibari Taarab and Kidumbak music, at the NYU Abu Dhabi Red Theater.

odd.head: Production
odd.p: Performers include:
Mixed by Aaron Marcus Willers (July 2022)

odd.head: Songs performed
odd.p: 1. Yalaiti = sung by Nima Ame. Originally from Siti bint Saad, recorded in the 1920's. 2. Kijiti = sung by Pili Ameir. Originally from Siti bint Saad, recorded in the 1920's. 3. Halikubaliki = composed and sung by Mohamed Othman for the first time in 2012. 4. Ashiki Baya = sung by Nima Ame. Originally from Siti bint Saad, recorded in the 1920's. 5. Alamina Dura = sung by Pili Ameir. Earliest traced recording by Bikidude in the 1980's. 6. Lulu = sung by Samir Ally. Composed and sung Professor Gogo in a recording from the 1990's (Professor Gogo is from Pemba island).

odd.p: 1. Yalaiti = sung by Nima Ame. Originally from Siti bint Saad, recorded in the 1920's. 2. Kijiti = sung by Pili Ameir. Originally from Siti bint Saad, recorded in the 1920's. 3. Halikubaliki = composed and sung by Mohamed Othman for the first time in 2012. 4. Ashiki Baya = sung by Nima Ame. Originally from Siti bint Saad, recorded in the 1920's. 5. Alamina Dura = sung by Pili Ameir. Earliest traced recording by Bikidude in the 1980's. 6. Lulu = sung by Samir Ally. Composed and sung Professor Gogo in a recording from the 1990's (Professor Gogo is from Pemba island).
